passages.text: Earnings review: 1H25 miss mainly due to lingering VBP impact; new product ramp up could accelerate in 2H; Buy
1066.HK 12m Price Target: HK\\$7.80 Price: HK\\$6.49 Upside: 20.2%

Weigao reported 1H25 flat revenue of Rmb6.6bn (+0.1% y/y) and declining net profit of Rmb1.0bn (- 9% y/y) in 1H25, with overall performance weaker than our expectation (3%/16% below GSe). Margin pressure was notable, driven by the prolonged impact of VBP on general consumables and pre- filled flush, and increased marketing expenses related to the launch of new vascular intervention products. R&D expense rose to Rmb316mn, accounting for 4.7% of revenue, up from 1H24 levels at 4.5%, reflecting the company's growing commitment to innovation with over 100 products currently under development. Foreign exchange losses, particularly in 2Q due to USD depreciation, resulted in a swing from Rmb20mn gain last year to Rmb40- 50mn loss this year. Operationally, OCF amounted to Rmb882mn, 14% lower than 1H24 due to 1) collections from direct sale channel were delayed by around Rmb100mn, while 2) strategic procurement efforts shortened supplier payment terms by Rmb140mn. Capex rose to Rmb400mn (vs 12/2412/25E12/26E12/27ERevenue (Rmb mn) New13,087.113,949.515,021.516,154.4Revenue (Rmb mn) Old13,087.114,292.315,507.016,698.9EBITDA (Rmb mn)3,242.43,320.03,561.53,858.3EPS (Rmb) New0.460.460.510.56EPS (Rmb) Old0.460.500.550.61P/E (X)9.713.011.810.7P/B (X)0.91.11.01.0Dividend yield (%)5.13.84.24.7CROCI (%)12.213.012.913.2

of \(+10 - 15\%\) and revised down our forecasts to \(+6.6\%\) y/y growth in 2025.

Segment revenues Rmb30bn, flat y/, while segment profit declined \(17.1\%\) y/y \((- 7\%\) y/y excluding FX effects). Key products such as infusion sets, indwelling venous catchers maintained stable pricing with single- digit volume growth while syringes a few other product categories saw single digit decline. Perioperative products achieved \(40\%\) growth and are emerging as a new driver. Equipment sales were limited in 1H due to training requirements but are expected to accelerate in 2H and could become the best performing sub- segment next year. The Liaoning- led alliance VBP rollout is expected in 2H, with manageable pricing impact due to mild rules and a revival mechanism. Management is focused on domestic substitution opportunities post- VBP, especially in sutures.

Pharma packaging remained flat y/y at Rmb1.17bn in revenue, with segment profit down \(5.8\%\) . Prefilled syringes (PFS) maintained market leadership and achieved single- digit growth with stable pricing. Overseas direct sales accounted for \(10\%\) of total volume, with Chinese biotech globalization driving packaging demand—now \(35\%\) of total volume, up \(10\%\) y/y. Prefilled flush syringes were affected by VBP led by Inner Mongolia, with average price down \(30\%\) and volume up \(10\%\) . Prices have now stabilized. Auto injectors saw strong domestic sales, up \(\sim 200\%\) y/y, driven by the obesity treatment, and now represent \(\sim 3\%\) of segment sales.

In orthopedics, spine products recorded double- digit y/y growth, while joint segment revenue declined y/y due to a shift to a distributor model, where 2H likely to see a recovery in terms of volume. The segment posted a \(74\%\) y/y profit increase on a low base and improved operational efficiency. Spine implants hold a top- three market position, and management is focused on the trend toward minimally invasive procedures. Sports medicine and tissue repair maintained double- digit y/y growth and the highest gross margin among all segments. Under the equity incentive plan, the orthopedics business targets Rmb290mn in net profit for 2025 (excluding incentive payments). Overseas sales remain low but are expected to grow with new materials' development.

Blood management revenue rose \(8.1\%\) y/y to Rmb450mn, driven by recovering overseas demand for Rad Source's X- ray blood irradiation equipment. Segment profit declined \(5.3\%\) y/y due to a lower- margin product mix, particularly in industrial irradiation. Total blood bag production capacity is expected to exceed 100 million units in 2025, covering \(75\%\) of the domestic market, with an additional 20 million
units planned for overseas markets.

Segment revenue was Rmb990mn, down by \(2\%\) y/y. Performance across the U.S., Europe, Middle East, and Africa regions showed a single- digit growth y/y and segment profit reached - Rmb89mn, primarily impacted by exchange rate fluctuations (Rmb40- 50mn) and increased sales marketing expenses (Rmb30- 40mn) following the launch of Cleaner Vac system, for which could accelerate in 2h).

Valuation and risks: We update our 2025- 27 net income estimates by \(- 8.5\% / - 8.7\% / - 8.7\%\) to reflect the impacts of US\$ depreciation on overseas and margin impact from VBP on general consumables and pre- filled flush. Our 12- m revised TP of HK\$7.8 (from HK\$8.0 prior) is based on a SOTP (using a 2027E exit P/E for 5 segments at a discount of \(9\%\) ) and reflect roll- over. We are Buy rated. Key downside risks: 1) uncertainty of VBP pricing cut; 2) less than expected market share gain with increasing selling expenses; 3) potentially less upside from new product ramp- up or M&A. 4) anti- corruption impact deeper than expected. Maintain Buy.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
